Thought: While entanglement purification via linear optics is well-studied, this proposal merely grafts a classical variational optimizer onto a standard two-link purification circuit. An almost identical variational approach has already been applied to swapping (\u201cVariational Low-Depth Bell-Measurement Node for Loss-Robust Entanglement Swapping\u201d) and more generally to programmable LOQC via machine learning in the ensemble suggestions. Merely tuning beam-splitters to maximize A\u2013D fidelity does not introduce a new measurement primitive or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new purification measurement or resource\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian ancilla, a new multi-photon interference effect, or a purification supermap\u2014rather than just parameter-tuning an existing swapping/purification ansatz.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement-Purification Supermap with Squeezed-Vacuum EPR Links and Single-Photon Ancilla  \nGoal: Starting from two imperfect two-mode squeezed-vacuum (SPDC) EPR pairs shared between nodes A\u2013B and C\u2013D, inject a single-photon ancilla at the intermediate node, apply a parameterized three-mode interferometer on modes B, C, and the ancilla (plus vacuum ancillas), and herald a specific multi-click pattern that projects A\u2013D into a higher-fidelity Bell state. A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phase shifts {\u03d5_i} to maximize fidelity (or negativity) of the final A\u2013D state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n            \u2198              \u2199  \n   Single-photon emitter: [4]  \n            \u2193  \n   Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum-ancillas [5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=5],[anc2=6],[anc3=7],[herald=4?]  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [4] (the non-Gaussian ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (prevent direct SPDC across nonadjacent modes)  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 3 vacuum-ancilla modes ([5,6,7])  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on detectors anc1\u2013anc3 (and optionally mode 4) that indicates successful purification  \n  \u2022 linear optics on modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] parameterized by a vector of angles/phases\u2014these parameters are adjusted externally via a classical optimizer  \n  \u2022 use number-resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization and Impact:\n  \u2013 Chains of these purification modules can form a full variational quantum-repeater.  \n  \u2013 One can explore different purification supermaps by changing the number or type of ancillas.  \n  \u2013 Bridges non-Gaussian resources (single photons) with squeezed-vacuum links under a variational design framework, opening a new class of optimized entanglement-distillation protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The core idea remains a classical variational tuning of an existing purification ansatz by injecting a single-photon ancilla into a linear-optics network\u2014a trivial enhancement on the prior two suggestions. It does not propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian supermap or measurement primitive beyond \u201ctweak beam-splitters and phases to boost fidelity,\u201d which overlaps with numerous ensemble variants (e.g. variational Bell-measurement nodes, POVM optimizers).  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal simply adds a single-photon ancilla to a standard purification circuit under variational control\u2014yet still lacks a fundamentally new non-Gaussian measurement primitive or resource beyond parameter tuning. To be novel, you must identify a measurement supermap or ancilla-driven interference effect not reducible to existing variational LOQC routines (e.g. a new multi-photon heralding pattern that enacts an irreducible non-Gaussian distillation step)."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"variational quantum algorithm\" and \"squeezed vacuum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A classical optimizer variationally adjusts the joint\u2010measurement linear\u2010optics network (beam-splitter angles and phase shifts) to maximize the entanglement (e.g. negativity or fidelity to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) between A and D, heralded by a specific click pattern on the ancillary detectors.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]  \n variational network design problem; instead of fixed parity\u2010check circuits, one optimizes a family of linear\u2010optics purification unitaries to maximize final Bell\u2010state fidelity.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses:  \n    \u2022 Two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum pair sources (abstract photon\u2010pair sources).  \n    \u2022 A static linear\u2010optics network on the intermediate modes plus vacuum ancillas (beam splitters, phase shifters).  \n    \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 A classical outer loop that chooses the beam\u2010splitter angles\u2014distinct from Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010circuit search.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement Purification with Squeezed\u2010Vacuum EPR Links  \nGoal: Starting from two imperfect two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum pairs shared between nodes A\u2013B and C\u2013D, implement a parameterized purification circuit on modes B and C (and vacuum ancillas) so that, upon a heralded detection pattern, modes A and D emerge in a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n   \u2198                         \u2199  \n   Purification network on modes [1,2] + vacuum\u2010ancilla modes [4,5,6,7]  \n   \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=4],[anc2=5],[anc3=6],[anc4=7]\n\nKey configuration for Pytheus:  \n\u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n\u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode pairs (0,1) and (2,3)  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (no direct SPDC linking nonadjacent modes)  \n\u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes  \n\u2022 parameterized linear\u2010optics network between modes [1,2,4,5,6,7], to be optimized externally (beam\u2010splitter angles \u03b8_i and phase shifts \u03c6_i)  \n\u2022 heralding_out: specify a particular click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that indicates successful purification  \n\u2022 use number\u2010resolving detectors on all ancillas circuits under realistic SPDC noise models.  \n\u2013 Opens a new avenue linking variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources in a fully linear\u2010optics, discrete\u2010detector framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new purification measurement or resource\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian ancilla, a new multi-photon interference effect, or a purification supermap\u2014rather than just parameter-tuning an existing swapping/purification ansatz.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstormed three ways to marry \u201cvariational quantum algorithm\u201d and \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network:\n    a) Variational entanglement swapping with SPDC links\u2014optimize joint\u2010measurement beamsplitters.  \n    b) Variational teleportation of a dual\u2010rail qubit over an SPDC EPR link\u2014optimize the recovery circuit.  \n    c) Variational entanglement-purification supermap: use two SPDC EPR links and a single-photon ancilla, optimize a three-mode interferometer to purify entanglement.  \n  Step 2: Checked novelty and feasibility:\n    a) too close to existing variational\u2010Bell\u2010swap proposals.  \n    b) teleportation with CV links requires displacements\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV model.  \n    c) no prior Pytheus experiments on variational purification supermaps; uses only SPDC sources, single-photon ancilla, linear optics, and photon detection\u2014fully within Pytheus.  \n  Step 3: Picked option (c).  \n  Step 4: Novelty: Casts entanglement purification as a tunable supermap\u2014injects a non-Gaussian resource (single photon) between two noisy squeezed-vacuum links, then variationally optimizes the multi-photon interference to maximize output entanglement. This goes beyond fixed CNOT-based distillation circuits.  \n  Step 5: Pytheus feasibility:  \n    \u2022 SPDC pair\u2010sources for squeezed-vacuum EPR links (abstract photon\u2010pair sources).  \n    \u2022 Single-photon emitter provides the non-Gaussian ancilla.  \n    \u2022 Static linear-optics network mixing the three modes + vacuum ancillas.  \n    \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 A classical outer loop adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles and phases\u2014kept outside Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010circuit search.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement-Purification Supermap with Squeezed-Vacuum EPR Links and Single-Photon Ancilla  \nGoal: Starting from two imperfect two-mode squeezed-vacuum (SPDC) EPR pairs shared between nodes A\u2013B and C\u2013D, inject a single-photon ancilla at the intermediate node, apply a parameterized three-mode interferometer on modes B, C, and the ancilla (plus vacuum ancillas), and herald a specific multi-click pattern that projects A\u2013D into a higher-fidelity Bell state. A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phase shifts {\u03d5_i} to maximize fidelity (or negativity) of the final A\u2013D state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n            \u2198              \u2199  \n   Single-photon emitter: [4]  \n            \u2193  \n   Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum-ancillas [5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=5],[anc2=6],[anc3=7],[herald=4?]  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [4] (the non-Gaussian ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (prevent direct SPDC across nonadjacent modes)  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 3 vacuum-ancilla modes ([5,6,7])  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on detectors anc1\u2013anc3 (and optionally mode 4) that indicates successful purification  \n  \u2022 linear optics on modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] parameterized by a vector of angles/phases\u2014these parameters are adjusted externally via a classical optimizer  \n  \u2022 use number-resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization and Impact:\n  \u2013 Chains of these purification modules can form a full variational quantum-repeater.  \n  \u2013 One can explore different purification supermaps by changing the number or type of ancillas.  \n  \u2013 Bridges non-Gaussian resources (single photons) with squeezed-vacuum links under a variational design framework, opening a new class of optimized entanglement-distillation protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal simply adds a single-photon ancilla to a standard purification circuit under variational control\u2014yet still lacks a fundamentally new non-Gaussian measurement primitive or resource beyond parameter tuning. To be novel, you must identify a measurement supermap or ancilla-driven interference effect not reducible to existing variational LOQC routines (e.g. a new multi-photon heralding pattern that enacts an irreducible non-Gaussian distillation step).\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM.     "output": "Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 different Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cvariational quantum algorithm\u201d and \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d in a quantum\u2010network task:\n    a) Variational entanglement swapping chain: SPDC links with beam\u2010splitter angles at each repeater node tuned to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement.\n    b) Variational teleportation over a CV EPR (squeezed\u2010vacuum) link, optimizing the LO recovery network\u2019s beam\u2010splitters to maximize fidelity of a dual\u2010rail qubit.\n    c) Variational entanglement\u2010routing \u201cswitch\u201d in a small photonic mesh: multiple SPDC EPR links feed a central interferometer whose beam\u2010splitter parameters are tuned to route entanglement between any chosen pair of end\u2010nodes.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    a) Too similar to existing variational\u2010Bell\u2010swap proposals.\n    b) Requires CV displacements & unknown\u2010state teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s DV abstract model.\n    c) No prior Pytheus experiment on entanglement routing/switching. Uses only SPDC sources, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors, and a classical outer loop to tune interferometer parameters. Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n  Step 3: Select (c): a variational entanglement\u2010router network.\n  Step 4: Novelty: Proposes the first variational quantum\u2010network \u201crouter\u201d for photonic EPR links\u2014tunes a central interferometer to dynamically allocate entanglement between any two end\u2010nodes on demand. Moves beyond fixed swapping circuits to a resource\u2010adaptive network code.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus: \n    \u2022 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources = abstract probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources.  \n    \u2022 Static interferometer on incoming modes + vacuum ancillas, parameterized by angles/ phases (optimized externally).  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback; all optics are static.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Routing Switch in a Photonic Mesh  \nGoal: Given four SPDC\u2010generated EPR links connecting a central node X to four outer nodes A, B, C, D, design a parameterized linear\u2010optics \u201crouter\u201d at X that\u2014upon a chosen heralding\u2010click pattern\u2014delivers a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between any two selected outer nodes (e.g. A & C). A classical optimizer variationally tunes the beam\u2010splitter angles and phase shifts in X\u2019s interferometer to maximize the output entanglement for each target pairing.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20134]  [1\u20135]  [2\u20136]  [3\u20137]  \n    (0=A,1=B,2=C,3=D; 4\u20137 feed into X)  \n             \u2198   \u2199  \n       Parameterized interferometer on modes [4,5,6,7] + vacuum ancillas [8,9,10,11]  \n             \u2193  \nDetectors: [A_out=0],[B_out=1],[C_out=2],[D_out=3],[anc1=8],[anc2=9],[anc3=10],[anc4=11]  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on the chosen output pair (e.g. modes [0,2] for A\u2013C)  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode\u2010pairs (0,4), (1,5), (2,6), (3,7)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,5],[0,6],[0,7],[2,4],[2,5],[2,7]] (and analogous for other pair runs)  \n    \u2013 Ensures each SPDC link only connects its designated outer mode and prevents unintended cross\u2010links  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes ([8\u201311])  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify a particular click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that heralds successful routing  \n  \u2022 linear\u2010optics network on modes [4\u20137,8\u201311] parameterized by a vector of beam\u2010splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phases {\u03d5_i}  \n    \u2013 These parameters are adjusted by an external classical optimizer (the \u201cvariational\u201d loop)  \n  \u2022 use number\u2010resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 By selecting different heralding patterns or retraining parameters, the same hardware routes entanglement between any chosen pair of end\u2010nodes\u2014an all\u2010optical entanglement \u201cswitch.\u201d  \n  \u2013 Can be scaled to larger meshes (N\u2010leaf routers) by adding SPDC links and ancillas.  \n  \u2013 Bridges variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources (squeezed vacua) in an all\u2010linear\u2010optics, discrete\u2010detection DV framework.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new research direction in optimizing quantum\u2010network routing primitives rather than fixed swapping/teleportation circuits."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Implemented in the PytHeus framework, our scheme uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, tunable beam-splitter reflectivities, ancilla detectors, and removed_connection constraints to enforce the binary-tree topology without dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated-Photonic Entanglement\u2010Dimension Splitting Supermap via Optical Metasurface  \n\nAbstract:  We propose an on-chip supermap that passively converts a single d\u00b2-dimensional Bell link between nodes A and B into two independent d-dimensional Bell links A\u2013C and B\u2013D, targeting the coherent \u201cdimension splitting\u201d of entanglement without active feed-forward.  The scheme employs two probabilistic photon-pair sources, one ancilla photon, a static (d\u00b2+1)\u00d7(d\u00b2+1) metasurface multiport and number-resolving heralding detectors, and is fully optimizable within the PyTheus framework as a new resource-multiplexing primitive for quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static Linear-Optical Analyzer for Four-Qubit Cluster-Basis Discrimination\n\nMini-abstract: We present a fully static, post-selected linear-optical module targeting the unambiguous discrimination of all four orthogonal four-qubit linear-cluster basis states. By mixing four signal photons with two Bell-pair ancillas in a fixed network of PBSs, 50:50 beam splitters and phase shifters, unique four-click polarization-resolved detection patterns herald which |C_{ij}\u27e9 cluster state was present without any active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network\n\nAbstract:  \nWe propose and analyze a one-shot multi-hop entanglement swap that compresses two sequential Bell-pair swaps across the target network A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D into a single four-photon joint interference measurement. By heralding one of 16 detector click patterns at a fixed 4-mode interferometer and applying local Pauli corrections, end nodes A and D are projected directly into a maximally entangled Bell state without intermediate feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nChiral-Edge Multi-Hop Entanglement Swapping on a Chern Photonic Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nThe target \u201cChiral-Edge Multi-Hop Entanglement Swapping on a Chern Photonic Lattice\u201d implements a linear-optical network in which sequential Bell measurements and ancilla photon swaps are forced to propagate strictly along a topologically protected one-way edge of a 2D Chern lattice, thereby distributing high-fidelity entanglement between distant output modes without generating forbidden multi-photon states. By restricting all Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors to allowed edge bonds, the scheme exploits the nontrivial Chern band topology to maintain robustness against static bulk defects and connectivity disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superactivation-Assisted Entanglement Distribution Under Amplitude Damping\n\nAbstract: We propose an experiment in which two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources generate Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3), and modes 1 & 2 traverse amplitude\u2010damped channels modeled by beam splitters coupling into ancilla modes 4 & 5. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Swapping Repeater Network  \nWe aim to distribute high\u2010fidelity Bell entanglement between two distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by connecting them with two two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (SPDC) sources at links A\u2013B and C\u2013D, and performing an intermediate, parameterized joint measurement at nodes B (mode 1) and C (mode 2). A classical optimizer variationally adjusts the joint\u2010measurement linear\u2010optics network (beam-splitter angles and phase shifts) to maximize the entanglement (e.g. negativity or fidelity to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) between A and D, heralded by a specific click pattern on the ancillary detectors.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]  \n [anc1=4],[anc2=5],[anc3=6],[anc4=7]  \n\nKey configuration elements for Pytheus:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11']  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode\u2010pairs (0,1) and (2,3) (default if single_emitters is empty)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]  \n      \u2013 ensures no direct source spans nonadjacent modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 used to herald successful swapping  \n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics network between modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] is parameterized by a set of beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i,\u03d5_i}, subject to external classical optimization  \n  \u2022 Use number\u2010resolving detectors  \n\nGeneralization and scientific impact:\n  \u2013 Extends standard entanglement swapping into a variational repeater design, potentially improving robustness to realistic SPDC imperfections.  \n  \u2013 Can be scaled to N links (multiple intermediate nodes) by chaining the same motif and optimizing a larger set of parameters.  \n  \u2013 Bridges the concept of variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources (squeezed vacua) in an all-linear-optics DV framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a variational version of entanglement swapping\u2014tuning a small linear\u2010optics network at the repeater to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end Bell fidelity\u2014already covered by the ensemble\u2019s \u201cVariational Low\u2010Depth Bell\u2010Measurement Node for Loss\u2010Robust Entanglement Swapping.\u201d The key novelty of using classical optimization to adjust beam\u2010splitters and phases for robust swapping under realistic loss is not new.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core idea\u2014variationally optimizing an intermediate joint measurement to boost heralded A\u2013D entanglement\u2014duplicates the \u201cVariational Low\u2010Depth Bell-Measurement Node for Loss-Robust Entanglement Swapping\u201d in the ensemble. phase shifts \u03c6_i)  \n\u2022 heralding_out: specify a particular click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that indicates successful purification  \n\u2022 use number\u2010resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2013 Chain this purification module across multiple segments to build a full variational quantum\u2010repeater protocol.  \n\u2013 Compare performance vs. fixed purification circuits under realistic SPDC noise models.  \n\u2013 Opens a new avenue linking variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources in a fully linear\u2010optics, discrete\u2010detector framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phase shifts {\u03d5_i} to maximize fidelity (or negativity) of the final A\u2013D state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n            \u2198              \u2199  \n   Single-photon emitter: [4]  \n            \u2193  \n pattern on detectors anc1\u2013anc3 (and optionally mode 4) that indicates successful purification  \n  \u2022 linear optics on modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] parameterized by a vector of angles/phases\u2014these parameters are adjusted externally via a classical optimizer  \n  \u2022 use number-resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization and Impact:\n  \u2013 Chains of Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. Feasible: uses only SPDC pair\u2010sources, static linear optics at intermediate nodes, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors, and an external classical loop to tune beam\u2010splitter angles.  \n  Step 3: Select (c).  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it brings the concept of entanglement percolation (finding long\u2010range entanglement in a graph of imperfect links) into a variational network\u2010design setting, optimizing local node optics rather than using fixed swapping circuits.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it employs:  \n    \u2022 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources = abstract probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on graph edges.  \n    \u2022 Static beam\u2010splitter + phase\u2010shifter networks at intermediate nodes (parameterized).  \n    \u2022 Vacuum ancillas & number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 A classical outer loop to adjust the node parameters (variational algorithm).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Percolation Network  \nGoal: Entangle two opposite corners of a 2\u00d71 SPDC network (nodes A and C) by using four imperfect two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum links arranged on a square graph A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A. ['00','11'] on output modes [0,4]  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on (0,1),(2,3),(4,5),(6,7)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:  \n      [[0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[0,7],[4,1],[4,3],[4,6],[4,7]]  \n    \u2013 Ensures no SPDC directly spans nonadjacent corners  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes ([8\u201311])  \n  \u2022 linear_optics network: two independent parameterized interferometers  \n      \u2013 at B on modes [1,2,8,9]  \n      \u2013 at D on modes [5,6,10,11]  \n    each defined by a set of beam\u2010splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phases {\u03d5_i}  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc_B1,B2, anc_D1,D2 that indicates successful percolation  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization and Impact:\n\n  \u2013 Scale to larger grids (M\u00d7N lattices) by adding more SPDC links and booster nodes.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010offs between network topology, resource squeezing, and local booster designs.  \n  \u2013 Pioneers a variational approach to entanglement percolation, bridging network theory, squeezed\u2010vacuum resources, and photonic optimization.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of experiments in quantum networks beyond fixed swapping or teleportation, enabling optimized long\u2010range entanglement distribution in realistic lossy settings."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. The scheme employs two probabilistic photon-pair sources, one ancilla photon, a static (d\u00b2+1)\u00d7(d\u00b2+1) metasurface multiport and number-resolving heralding detectors, and is fully optimizable within the PyTheus framework as a new resource-multiplexing primitive for quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node. Upon a specific four-click detection pattern, the unmeasured remote modes collapse into the target qubit Bell state, achieving the conversion from two qutrit Bell pairs to one qubit Bell pair.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Linear-Optical Four-Body Parity-Phase Gate for Digital Kitaev Hamiltonian Simulation\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe introduce a static, post-selected linear-optical gadget that implements the four-qubit parity-phase unitaries U\u2093=exp(\u2212i\u03c0X\u2081X\u2082X\u2083X\u2084/4) and U_z=exp(\u2212i\u03c0Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084/4) corresponding to the star and plaquette terms of the Kitaev Hamiltonian via Bell-pair ancillas, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number\u2013resolving detectors. Concatenating U\u2093 then U_z in a single heralded Trotter step realizes one digital interaction unitary e^{\u2212i\u03b8H_Kitaev} on four photonic qubits, enabling network-based simulation of topological codes without requiring state generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Photonic Projector onto Two-Qubit Heisenberg Ground-State Manifolds\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded, reconfigurable two-qubit linear-optical module that postselectively projects arbitrary photon-encoded qubit inputs onto the ground-state manifold of the tunable two-body Heisenberg Hamiltonian H(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8\u2009(\u03c3\u2093\u03c3\u2093+\u03c3_y\u03c3_y)+sin \u03b8\u2009\u03c3_z\u03c3_z\u2014realizing the antisymmetric singlet subspace at \u03b8=0 or the symmetric triplet subspace at \u03b8=\u03c0/2. By using two ancilla photons, a four-mode interferometer with adjustable internal phases, and number-resolving detectors to signal success, the device achieves the target projection and can be chained via entanglement swapping to simulate and distribute spin-chain ground-state correlations across a fully programmable photonic network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By toggling between the \u201ctrivial\u201d edge-bond connectivity (sources on outer edges) and the \u201ctopological\u201d central-plaquette connectivity (sources on interior bonds), we compare heralded success probabilities\u2014equivalent to effective teleportation fidelities\u2014to directly probe the corner-mode protection predicted for higher-order photonic quadruple insulators.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'.     "output": "Thought: This proposal is just a variational wrapper around an entanglement\u2010percolation primitive\u2014optimizing local \u201cboosters\u201d at B and D to herald a Bell link between A\u2013C. Entanglement percolation via linear\u2010optics has already been explored (e.g. measurement\u2010induced percolation on lattices and multi\u2010path percolation schemes in the ensemble), so merely tuning beam\u2010splitter angles in a 2\u00d71 square graph does not introduce a genuinely new supermap or resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new percolation measurement primitive\u2014such as a non-Gaussian ancilla\u2010driven booster, indefinite\u2010order percolation switch, or higher-point measurement supermap\u2014that cannot be reduced to existing variational tuning of local beam-splitter networks."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"variational quantum algorithm\" and \"squeezed vacuum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. experiments in the list; uses only SPDC pair sources, linear optics, vacuum ancillas, photon detection, and a classical outer loop to tune beam\u2010splitters\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  Step 3: Select (c) as the most promising idea.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because entanglement purification with squeezed\u2010vacuum EPR links has never been cast as a variational network design problem; instead of fixed parity\u2010check circuits, one optimizes a family of linear\u2010optics purification unitaries to maximize final Bell\u2010state fidelity.  \n the beam\u2010splitter angles\u2014distinct from Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010circuit search.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement Purification with Squeezed\u2010Vacuum EPR Links  \nGoal: Starting from two imperfect two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum pairs shared between nodes A\u2013B and C\u2013D, implement a parameterized purification circuit on modes B and C (and vacuum ancillas) so that, upon a heralded detection pattern, modes A and D emerge in a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n   \u2198                         \u2199  \n   Purification network on modes [1,2] + vacuum\u2010ancilla modes [4,5,6,7]  \n   \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=4],[anc2=5],[anc3=6],[anc4=7]\n\nKey configuration for Pytheus:  \n\u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n\u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode pairs (0,1) and (2,3)  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (no direct SPDC linking nonadjacent modes)  \n\u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes  \n\u2022 parameterized linear\u2010optics network between modes [1,2,4,5,6,7], to be optimized externally (beam\u2010splitter angles \u03b8_i and phase shifts \u03c6_i)  \n\u2022 heralding_out: specify a particular click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that indicates successful purification  \n\u2022 use number\u2010resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2013 Chain this purification module across multiple segments to build a full variational quantum\u2010repeater protocol.  \n\u2013 Compare performance vs. fixed purification circuits under realistic SPDC noise models.  \n\u2013 Opens a new avenue linking variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources in a fully linear\u2010optics, discrete\u2010detector framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new purification measurement or resource\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian ancilla, a new {
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node.
