By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Linear-Optical Four-Body Parity-Phase Gate for Digital Kitaev Hamiltonian Simulation\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe introduce a static, post-selected linear-optical gadget that implements the four-qubit parity-phase unitaries U\u2093=exp(\u2212i\u03c0X\u2081X\u2082X\u2083X\u2084/4) and U_z=exp(\u2212i\u03c0Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084/4) corresponding to the star and plaquette terms of the Kitaev Hamiltonian via Bell-pair ancillas, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number\u2013resolving detectors. Concatenating U\u2093 then U_z in a single heralded Trotter step realizes one digital interaction unitary e^{\u2212i\u03b8H_Kitaev} on four photonic qubits, enabling network-based simulation of topological codes without requiring state generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Photonic Projector onto Two-Qubit Heisenberg Ground-State Manifolds\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded, reconfigurable two-qubit linear-optical module that postselectively projects arbitrary photon-encoded qubit inputs onto the ground-state manifold of the tunable two-body Heisenberg Hamiltonian H(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8\u2009(\u03c3\u2093\u03c3\u2093+\u03c3_y\u03c3_y)+sin \u03b8\u2009\u03c3_z\u03c3_z\u2014realizing the antisymmetric singlet subspace at \u03b8=0 or the symmetric triplet subspace at \u03b8=\u03c0/2. By using two ancilla photons, a four-mode interferometer with adjustable internal phases, and number-resolving detectors to signal success, the device achieves the target projection and can be chained via entanglement swapping to simulate and distribute spin-chain ground-state correlations across a fully programmable photonic network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nCorner-Protected Bell\u2013Swap Teleportation in a 3\u00d73 Photonic Quadruple-Insulator Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a 3\u00d73 photonic quadruple-insulator network to teleport quantum information between modes 0 and 8 via two successive Bell-state measurements, heralding the target Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2088 (i.e. \u201c00\u201d\u2013\u201c11\u201d) through intermediate swaps on modes (1,4) and (4,7). By toggling between the \u201ctrivial\u201d edge-bond connectivity (sources on outer edges) and the \u201ctopological\u201d central-plaquette connectivity (sources on interior bonds), we compare heralded success probabilities\u2014equivalent to effective teleportation fidelities\u2014to directly probe the corner-mode protection predicted for higher-order photonic quadruple insulators.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. \u2022 heralding_out: specify a multi-click pattern on ancB1, ancB2, ancD1, ancD2 that signals successful percolation  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization & Scientific Impact:\n  \u2013 Scale to larger lattices (M\u00d7N graphs) by adding SPDC edges and percolation boosters.  \n  \u2013 Investigate new non-Gaussian percolation thresholds and resource trade-offs between squeezing, ancilla number, and circuit depth.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational quantum-network primitives\u2014percolation supermaps that leverage single-photon catalysis on squeezed-vacuum links.  \n  \u2013 Bridges modern variational quantum algorithms with continuous-variable resources in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While introducing single-photon ancillas into the 2\u00d72 percolation square is a slight twist, this proposal remains a variational parameter\u2010tuning of a known entanglement\u2010percolation primitive rather than a genuinely new measurement supermap or resource. The core percolation concept\u2014boosting Bell links at intermediate nodes via local linear\u2010optics and heralding\u2014is already embodied in several ensemble suggestions (e.g. measurement\u2010induced percolation and noisy\u2010channel boosters). Wrapping it in a classical optimizer does not suffice for PRL\u2010level novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: You must propose a fundamentally new non-Gaussian percolation measurement primitive (e.g. a multi-photon catalysis supermap or indefinite-order percolation protocol) that cannot be reduced to tuning beam-splitters and phases on a 2\u00d72 SPDC square."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. algorithm\u201d and \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network target:  \n    a) Variational entanglement\u2010swapping chains where each link is a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum (SPDC) source and the intermediate joint measurement\u2019s beam\u2010splitter angles are variationally optimized.  \n    b) Teleportation of a dual\u2010rail encoded qubit via continuous\u2010variable EPR (squeezed\u2010vacuum) links, with a static, parameterized linear\u2010optics recovery circuit tuned by a classical optimizer to maximize fidelity.  \n    c) Entanglement\u2010purification protocol: two noisy EPR links (squeezed vacua) between A\u2013B and C\u2013D, then a variational linear\u2010optics purification network on B\u2013C coupled with vacuum ancillas, heralded by photon detection.  \n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus\u2010compatibility check:  \n    a) Similar to known variational\u2010Bell\u2010measurements for swapping\u2014runs risk of duplication.  \n    b) Requires teleportation of arbitrary unknown states and CV recovery (displacements), not easily captured by Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV framework.  \n    c) No prior purification experiments in the list; uses only SPDC pair sources, linear optics, vacuum ancillas, photon detection, and a classical outer loop to tune beam\u2010splitters\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  Step 3: Select (c) as the most promising idea.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because entanglement purification with squeezed\u2010vacuum EPR links has never been cast as a variational network design problem; instead of fixed parity\u2010check circuits, one optimizes a family of linear\u2010optics purification unitaries to maximize final Bell\u2010state fidelity.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses:  \n    \u2022 Two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum pair sources (abstract photon\u2010pair sources).  \n    \u2022 A static linear\u2010optics network on the intermediate modes plus vacuum ancillas (beam splitters, phase shifters).  \n    \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 A classical outer loop that chooses the beam\u2010splitter angles\u2014distinct from Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010circuit search.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n   \u2198                         \u2199  \n   Purification network on modes [1,2] + output modes [0,3]  \n\u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode pairs (0,1) and (2,3)  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (no direct SPDC linking nonadjacent modes) This goes beyond fixed CNOT-based distillation circuits.  \n  Step 5: Pytheus feasibility:  \n    \u2022 SPDC pair\u2010sources for squeezed-vacuum EPR links (abstract photon\u2010pair sources).  \n    \u2022 Single-photon emitter provides the non-Gaussian ancilla.  \n    \u2022 Static linear-optics network mixing the three modes + vacuum ancillas.  \n    \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 A classical outer loop adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles and phases\u2014kept outside Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010circuit search.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement-Purification Supermap with Squeezed-Vacuum EPR Links and Single-Photon Ancilla  \nGoal: Starting from two imperfect two-mode squeezed-vacuum (SPDC) EPR pairs shared between nodes A\u2013B and C\u2013D, inject a single-photon ancilla at the intermediate node, apply a parameterized three-mode interferometer on modes B, C, and the ancilla (plus vacuum ancillas), and herald a specific multi-click pattern that projects A\u2013D into a higher-fidelity Bell state. A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phase shifts {\u03d5_i} to maximize fidelity (or negativity) of the final A\u2013D state.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]       [2\u20133]  \n            \u2198              \u2199  \n   Single-photon emitter: [4]  \n            \u2193  \n   Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum-ancillas [5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=5],[anc2=6],[anc3=7],[herald=4?]  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [4] (the non-Gaussian ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (prevent direct SPDC across nonadjacent modes)  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 3 vacuum-ancilla modes ([5,6,7])  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on detectors anc1\u2013anc3 (and optionally mode 4) that indicates successful purification  \n  \u2022 linear optics on modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] parameterized by a vector of angles/phases\u2014these parameters are adjusted externally via a classical optimizer  \n  \u2022 use number-resolving detectors on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization and Impact:\n  \u2013 Chains of these purification modules can form a full variational quantum-repeater.  \n  \u2013 One can explore different purification supermaps by changing the number or type of ancillas.  \n  \u2013 Bridges non-Gaussian resources (single photons) with squeezed-vacuum links under a variational design framework, opening a new class of optimized entanglement-distillation protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal simply adds a single-photon ancilla to a standard purification circuit under variational control\u2014yet still lacks a fundamentally new non-Gaussian measurement primitive or resource beyond parameter tuning. Scientific Impact:\n  \u2013 Scale to larger lattices (M\u00d7N graphs) by adding SPDC edges and percolation boosters.  \n  \u2013 Investigate new non-Gaussian percolation thresholds and resource trade-offs between squeezing, ancilla number, and circuit depth.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational quantum-network primitives\u2014percolation supermaps that leverage single-photon catalysis on squeezed-vacuum links.  \n  \u2013 Bridges modern variational quantum algorithms with continuous-variable resources in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: You must propose a fundamentally new non-Gaussian percolation measurement primitive (e.g. a multi-photon catalysis supermap or indefinite-order percolation protocol) that cannot be reduced to tuning beam-splitters and phases on a 2\u00d72 SPDC square.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstormed three ways to marry \u201cvariational quantum algorithm\u201d with \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d:\n    a) Variational entanglement\u2010swapping over SPDC links\u2014tune Bell\u2010measurement optics.\n    b) Variational teleportation of a dual\u2010rail qubit through SPDC EPR link\u2014tune recovery optics.\n    c) Variational non\u2010Gaussian entanglement\u2010percolation on an SPDC square network\u2014inject single-photon ancillas and tune local interferometers to catalyze percolation.\n  Step 2: Feasibility & novelty:\n    a) Too similar to known variational\u2010swap proposals.\n    b) Requires CV displacements\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV model.\n    c) Novel: no prior Pytheus work on non\u2010Gaussian catalysis\u2010based percolation. Uses only SPDC sources, single-photon emitters, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection, plus an external variational loop.\n  Step 3: Chose (c).\n  Step 4: Novelty: Introduces a non\u2010Gaussian \u201cphoton\u2010catalysis\u201d supermap at each intermediate node\u2014mixing squeezed\u2010vacuum link modes with a single-photon ancilla\u2014enabling entanglement percolation beyond Gaussian limits, and cast as a variational algorithm.\n  Step 5: Pytheus feasibility:\n    \u2022 Two-mode squeezed vacua = abstract photon-pair sources.\n    \u2022 single_emitters for non-Gaussian ancillas.\n    \u2022 Static beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing link modes, ancilla, and vacuum ancillas.\n    \u2022 Number-resolving detectors for heralding.\n    \u2022 External classical loop chooses beam-splitter angles/ phases.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Photon-Catalyzed Entanglement-Percolation on a 2\u00d72 SPDC Square  \nGoal: Share a high-fidelity Bell pair between opposite corners A and C of a square of four imperfect two-mode squeezed-vacuum links (SPDC). At intermediate nodes B and D, inject a single-photon ancilla to enact a non-Gaussian \u201cphoton-catalysis\u201d supermap: mix the two incoming SPDC modes with the ancilla and vacuum ancillas in a tunable interferometer, then herald specific photon-count patterns to boost percolation. A classical optimizer variationally adjusts beam-splitter angles and phase shifts at both boosters to maximize the heralded entanglement between A and C.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n  SPDC sources:  \n    A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    B\u2013C: modes [2\u20133]  \n    C\u2013D: modes [4\u20135]  \n    D\u2013A: modes [6\u20137]  \n\n      \u2198                \u2199      \u2198                \u2199  \n  Booster at B: interferometer on [1,2] + single-photon ancilla [8] + vacuum ancillas [9,10]  \n  Booster at D: interferometer on [5,6] + single-photon ancilla [11] + vacuum ancillas [12,13]  \n      \u2193                \u2193  \n  Detectors: [A_out=0], [C_out=4], ancB1=9, ancB2=10, ancD1=12, ancD2=13  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on modes [0,4]  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1),(2,3),(4,5),(6,7)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [8,11]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:  \n      [[0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[0,7],[4,1],[4,3],[4,6],[4,7]]  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum-ancilla modes ([9,10,12,13])  \n  \u2022 linear_optics: two independent parameterized interferometers  \n      \u2013 at B mixing modes [1,2,8,9,10]  \n      \u2013 at D mixing modes [5,6,11,12,13]  \n    each defined by beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phases {\u03d5_i}  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: click pattern on ancB1, ancB2, ancD1, ancD2 indicates successful percolation  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 Extend to larger lattices (M\u00d7N graphs) with more boosters.  \n  \u2013 Explore non-Gaussian percolation thresholds vs. Gaussian limits.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational, catalysis-enhanced network primitives in photonic quantum networks, combining squeezed-vacuum resources with modern variational design."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. The scheme employs two probabilistic photon-pair sources, one ancilla photon, a static (d\u00b2+1)\u00d7(d\u00b2+1) metasurface multiport and number-resolving heralding detectors, and is fully optimizable within the PyTheus framework as a new resource-multiplexing primitive for quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Programmable Photonic Teleportation Router for Three Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a three-input/three-output linear-optical network\u2014the Programmable Photonic Teleportation Router for Three Qubits\u2014that, under a classical \u201cprogram\u201d of three static phase-shifter settings, permutes and teleports three unknown qubits from senders Alice\u2081, Alice\u2082, Alice\u2083 onto receivers Bob\u208d\u03c0(1)\u208e, Bob\u208d\u03c0(2)\u208e, Bob\u208d\u03c0(3)\u208e for any \u03c0\u2208S\u2083. By combining three probabilistic EPR photon-pair sources, a programmable six-mode interferometer, and post-selected Bell measurements, this novel quantum-network primitive realizes fully programmable routing of unknown qubits without dynamic feed-forward or cavity resources.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nReusable Catalytic Entanglement Swapping for Enhanced EPR Link Generation\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe demonstrate a linear-optical \u201ccatalytic\u201d entanglement-swapping protocol that employs a permanent EPR pair (the X\u2032\u2013Y\u2032 catalyst) to boost the long-term entanglement generation rate between nodes A and B without consuming the catalyst link. By mixing three probabilistic photon-pair sources in a passive six-mode interferometer and number-resolving detection, we herald simultaneous Bell pairs on modes [0,1] (A\u2013B) and [6,7] (X\u2032\u2013Y\u2032), thereby achieving repeated high-rate entanglement between A and B while preserving the reusable resource link.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nDirect Single-Shot Measurement of the Second R\u00e9nyi OTOC in a Four-Site Atom Array via Photonic Interferometry  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe propose a fully linear-optical protocol to measure the second R\u00e9nyi out-of-time-ordered correlator O\u2082(t)=\u27e8W\u2081(t)V\u2084W\u2081(t)V\u2084\u27e9 on a four-qubit atom array in a single shot. By encoding each \u201catom\u201d qubit as a dual-rail single photon, inserting Pauli-X operations through local phase flips, and deploying two Bell-pair ancillas for parallel swap-test subcircuits, a Pythues-optimized 4\u00d74 interferometer implements U(t) and U\u2020(t) and heralds the OTOC value via zero-click correlations on number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node. swapping/teleportation circuits.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"variational quantum algorithm\" and \"squeezed vacuum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cvariational quantum algorithm\u201d and \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d in a network experiment:\n    a) Variational entanglement\u2010swapping chain over SPDC links\u2014tune intermediate Bell\u2010measurement beam\u2010splitters to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement.\n    b) Variational teleportation of a dual\u2010rail qubit over a CV EPR (squeezed\u2010vacuum) link\u2014tune the recovery linear optics for maximum fidelity.\n    c) Variational squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010assisted Bell\u2010state analyzer\u2014inject a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla into a Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, then variationally optimize beam\u2010splitter angles and phases to discriminate all four Bell states.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    a) Too close to existing variational\u2010Bell\u2010swap proposals.\n    b) Requires CV displacements and unknown\u2010state teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV model.\n    c) Novel\u2014no prior Pytheus experiment using squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas for Bell\u2010measurement; uses only SPDC pair sources, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors, plus an outer variational loop.\n  Step 3: Select option (c).\n  Step 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal to cast Bell\u2010state discrimination as a variational task that leverages a continuous\u2010variable resource (squeezed vacuum) to break the 50% linear-optics limit, by optimizing a static interferometer\u2019s parameters.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: It uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (for both input and squeezed vacuum ancilla), static beam\u2010splitters and phase-shifters, vacuum ancillas, photon\u2010number-resolving detectors, and an external classical optimizer for the optical parameters\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nVariational Squeezed-Vacuum-Assisted Bell-State Analyzer\n\nGoal:\nDesign a Bell\u2010measurement that unambiguously discriminates all four two-qubit Bell states using only linear optics, a single two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla, vacuum ancillas, and photon-number-resolving detection. A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles and phase shifts to maximize the average discrimination fidelity (or success probability) over the four Bell inputs.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Input qubit modes: [0,1]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla (SPDC source): modes [2,3]  \n  Vacuum ancillas: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n  Parameterized linear-optics network on modes [0\u20137]  \n            \u2193  \n  Detectors: [det0=0],[det1=1],[det2=2],[det3=3],[anc4=4],[anc5=5],[anc6=6],[anc7=7]\n\nConfiguration for Pytheus:\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum-assisted Bell-state analyzer\"\n  foldername: \"VQA_SV_BSA\"\n  target_quantum: ['10000000','01000000','00100000','00010000']\n    \u2013 maps the four Bell input states to four orthogonal single-click patterns on detectors 0\u20133  \n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: on mode pairs (0,1) (the input Bell pair) and (2,3) (the squeezed-vacuum ancilla)\n  num_anc: 4\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []\n  bursts_thr: 0.0\n  edges_tried: 50\n  ftol: 1e-6\n  loss_func: \"cr\"\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples: 10\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1]\n  number_resolving: True\n  heralding_out: None (the analyzer succeeds when exactly one click occurs in detectors 0\u20133 and none in 4\u20137)\n  topopt: None\n  seed: None\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 External variational loop can re-optimize for different noise models or detector efficiencies.  \n  \u2013 Can be extended to higher-dimensional Bell-state analysis using multi-mode squeezed vacua.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational measurement tasks in quantum networks, leveraging continuous-variable ancillas in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection setting."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nCorner-Protected Bell\u2013Swap Teleportation in a 3\u00d73 Photonic Quadruple-Insulator Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a 3\u00d73 photonic quadruple-insulator network to teleport quantum information between modes 0 and 8 via two successive Bell-state measurements, heralding the target Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2088 (i.e. \u201c00\u201d\u2013\u201c11\u201d) through intermediate swaps on modes (1,4) and (4,7). By toggling between the \u201ctrivial\u201d edge-bond connectivity (sources on outer edges) and the \u201ctopological\u201d central-plaquette connectivity (sources on interior bonds), we compare heralded success probabilities\u2014equivalent to effective teleportation fidelities\u2014to directly probe the corner-mode protection predicted for higher-order photonic quadruple insulators.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. ancB1, ancB2, ancD1, ancD2 indicates successful percolation  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 Extend to larger lattices (M\u00d7N graphs) with more boosters.  \n  \u2013 Explore non-Gaussian percolation thresholds vs. Gaussian limits.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational, catalysis-enhanced network primitives in photonic quantum networks, combining squeezed-vacuum resources with modern variational design.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While injecting single\u2010photon ancillas into the percolation boosters adds a non\u2010Gaussian twist, the proposal remains a classical variational wrapper around the well\u2010studied entanglement\u2010percolation primitive on a 2\u00d72 SPDC square. Similar network\u2013percolation schemes (static and topological) and photon\u2010catalysis/distillation recipes already appear in the ensemble, and wrapping them in a parameter search does not constitute a new supermap or fundamental measurement resource.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you must identify a genuinely new percolation measurement primitive (for example a multi\u2010photon catalysis supermap or indefinite\u2010order percolation protocol) that cannot be reduced to tuning beam splitters and phases on an existing 2\u00d72 SPDC lattice.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nVariational Squeezed-Vacuum-Assisted Bell-State Analyzer\n\nGoal:\nDesign a Bell\u2010measurement that unambiguously discriminates all four two-qubit Bell states using only linear optics, a single two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla, vacuum ancillas, and photon-number-resolving detection. A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles and phase shifts to maximize the average discrimination fidelity (or success probability) over the four Bell inputs.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Input qubit modes: [0,1]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla (SPDC source): modes [2,3]  \n  Vacuum ancillas: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n  Parameterized linear-optics network on modes [0\u20137]  \n            \u2193  \n  Detectors: [det0=0],[det1=1],[det2=2],[det3=3],[anc4=4],[anc5=5],[anc6=6],[anc7=7]\n\nConfiguration for Pytheus:\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum-assisted Bell-state analyzer\"\n  foldername: \"VQA_SV_BSA\"\n  target_quantum: ['10000000','01000000','00100000','00010000']\n    \u2013 maps the four Bell input states to four orthogonal single-click patterns on detectors 0\u20133  \n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: on mode pairs (0,1) (the input Bell pair) and (2,3) (the squeezed-vacuum ancilla)\n  num_anc: 4\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []\n  bursts_thr: 0.0\n  edges_tried: 50\n  ftol: 1e-6\n  loss_func: \"cr\"\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples: 10\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1]\n  number_resolving: True\n  heralding_out: None (the analyzer succeeds when exactly one click occurs in detectors 0\u20133 and none in 4\u20137)\n  topopt: None\n  seed: None\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 External variational loop can re-optimize for different noise models or detector efficiencies.  \n  \u2013 Can be extended to higher-dimensional Bell-state analysis using multi-mode squeezed vacua.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational measurement tasks in quantum networks, leveraging continuous-variable ancillas in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection setting.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While leveraging a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla in a variational Bell\u2010measurement is interesting, this proposal essentially replicates the ensemble\u2019s \u201cVariational Bell\u2010State POVM with Two\u2010Mode Squeezed\u2010Vacuum Ancillas,\u201d merely reducing ancilla count and wrapping it in an optimizer. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. A classical optimizer variationally adjusts the joint\u2010measurement linear\u2010optics network (beam-splitter angles and phase shifts) to maximize the entanglement (e.g. negativity or fidelity to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) between A and D, heralded by a specific click pattern on the ancillary detectors.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]  \n            \u2198\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2199  \n       Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2] + 4 ancillary vacuum inputs  \n            \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], [anc1=4],[anc2=5],[anc3=6],[anc4=7]  \n\nKey configuration elements for Pytheus:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11']  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on mode\u2010pairs (0,1) and (2,3) (default if single_emitters is empty)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]  \n      \u2013 ensures no direct source spans nonadjacent modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 used to herald successful swapping  \n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics network between modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] is parameterized by a set of beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i,\u03d5_i}, subject to external classical optimization  \n  \u2022 Use number\u2010resolving detectors  \n\nGeneralization and scientific impact:\n  \u2013 Extends standard entanglement swapping into a variational repeater design, potentially improving robustness to realistic SPDC imperfections.  \n  \u2013 Can be scaled to N links (multiple intermediate nodes) by chaining the same motif and optimizing a larger set of parameters.  \n  \u2013 Bridges the concept of variational quantum algorithms with continuous\u2010variable resources (squeezed vacua) in an all-linear-optics DV framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core idea\u2014variationally optimizing an intermediate joint measurement to boost heralded A\u2013D entanglement\u2014duplicates the \u201cVariational Low\u2010Depth Bell-Measurement Node for Loss-Robust Entanglement Swapping\u201d in the ensemble. uses only SPDC pair-sources, single-photon emitters, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, number-resolving detectors, plus an external classical loop for parameter tuning.\n  Step 3: Selected (c).\n  Step 4: Novelty: Proposes the first variational entanglement-percolation supermap that injects a single-photon ancilla (a non-Gaussian resource) at each intermediate node to enact a purification\u2010style \u201ccatalysis\u201d filter\u2014tuning local interferometers to achieve a percolation threshold unachievable with Gaussian optics alone.\n  Step 5: Pytheus feasibility: \n    \u2022 SPDC two-mode squeezed-vacuum links are abstract photon-pair sources.\n    \u2022 Single-photon emitter ancillas at percolation nodes are allowed via single_emitters.\n    \u2022 Static linear-optics networks (beam-splitters & phases) at nodes B and D mixing incoming link modes, the single-photon ancilla, and vacuum ancillas.\n    \u2022 Number-resolving detection for heralding.\n    \u2022 A classical outer loop variationally chooses beam-splitter angles and phases\u2014outside Pytheus\u2019s static search.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Non-Gaussian Entanglement-Percolation on a 2\u00d72 SPDC Square  \nGoal: Distribute a high-fidelity Bell pair between opposite corners A and C of a 2\u00d72 square network of four imperfect two-mode squeezed-vacuum (SPDC) EPR links by using single-photon ancillas and tunable \u201cpercolation boosters\u201d at the intermediate nodes B and D. percolation alone can yield.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources (two-mode squeezed vacua):\n    A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    B\u2013C: modes [2\u20133]  \n    C\u2013D: A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles and phase shifts to maximize the average discrimination fidelity (or success probability) over the four Bell inputs.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Input qubit modes: [0,1]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla (SPDC source): modes [2,3]  \n  Vacuum ancillas: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n  Parameterized linear-optics network on modes [0\u20137]  \n            \u2193  \n  Detectors: [det0=0],[det1=1],[det2=2],[det3=3],[anc4=4],[anc5=5],[anc6=6],[anc7=7]\n\nConfiguration for Pytheus:\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum-assisted Bell-state analyzer\"\n  foldername: \"VQA_SV_BSA\"\n  target_quantum: ['10000000','01000000','00100000','00010000']\n    \u2013 maps the four Bell input states to four orthogonal single-click patterns on detectors 0\u20133  \n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: on mode pairs (0,1) (the input Bell pair) and (2,3) (the squeezed-vacuum ancilla)\n  num_anc: 4\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []\n  bursts_thr: 0.0\n  edges_tried: 50\n  ftol: 1e-6\n  loss_func: \"cr\"\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples: 10\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1]\n  number_resolving: True\n  heralding_out: None (the analyzer succeeds when exactly one click occurs in detectors 0\u20133 and none in 4\u20137)\n  topopt: None\n  seed: None\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 External variational loop can re-optimize for different noise models or detector efficiencies.  \n  \u2013 Can be extended to higher-dimensional Bell-state analysis using multi-mode squeezed vacua.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational measurement tasks in quantum networks, leveraging continuous-variable ancillas in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection setting.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core concept overlaps the ensemble\u2019s variational squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell\u2010POVM.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to combine \u201cvariational quantum algorithm\u201d and \u201csqueezed vacuum state\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network target:\n    a) Variational Bell\u2010measurement assisted by a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla\u2014optimize beam\u2010splitters to boost unambiguous Bell\u2010discrimination.\n    b) Variational entanglement\u2010routing switch in a photonic mesh\u2014use SPDC links and tune a central interferometer to route entanglement on demand.\n    c) Variational photon\u2010catalyzed dual\u2010hop teleportation: use two SPDC EPR links A\u2013B and B\u2013C plus single\u2010photon ancillas at node B, then variationally optimize B\u2019s interferometer to maximize teleportation fidelity from A to C.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility check:\n    a) Too close to known squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers.\n    b) Routing ideas exist in fixed form; lacks a non\u2010Gaussian twist.\n    c) Novel: casts two\u2010link teleportation as a variational \u201ccatalysis\u201d network using squeezed vacua and single photons, a transformation (teleportation) not state generation. Feasible: uses only SPDC pair\u2010sources, single\u2010photon emitters, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The outer classical loop adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles\u2014outside Pytheus.\n  Step 3: Select idea (c).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it transforms the standard two\u2010link entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation into a variational \u201cphoton\u2010catalyzed\u201d network: injecting non\u2010Gaussian ancillas at the repeater node and optimizing its static interferometer to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation fidelity, instead of using a fixed Bell\u2010swap.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n    \u2022 Two SPDC links are abstract probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3).  \n    \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters at node B (mode 4) supply the non\u2010Gaussian ancilla.  \n    \u2022 Static linear\u2010optics on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [5\u20138], all describable by beam\u2010splitters and phases.  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors herald successes.  \n    \u2022 An external classical optimizer sets the beam\u2010splitter angles and phases\u2014Pytheus only needs to search the static circuit form.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Photon\u2010Catalyzed Dual\u2010Hop Teleportation  \nGoal: Teleport an unknown dual\u2010rail qubit held in modes A\u2080/A\u2081 (nodes 0,1) to modes C\u2080/C\u2081 (nodes 2,3) across two imperfect SPDC EPR links (A\u2192B and B\u2192C) by injecting a single\u2010photon ancilla at the intermediate node B (mode 4). A parametrized static interferometer at B mixes the two incoming EPR modes and the ancilla (plus vacuum ancillas), and a specific heralding click pattern projects modes A and C into the teleported state. A classical variational loop adjusts the interferometer\u2019s beam\u2010splitter angles {\u03b8\u1d62} and phase shifts {\u03d5\u1d62} to maximize teleportation fidelity.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources:  \n    Link A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131)  \n    Link B\u2013C (modes 2\u20133)  \n      \u2198       \u2199  \n  Single-photon emitter at B: mode 4  \n      \u2193  \n  Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [5,6,7,8]  \n      \u2193  \n  Detectors:  \n    A_out=0, A_out=1  \n    C_out=2, C_out=3  \n    anc1=5, anc2=6, anc3=7, anc4=8  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration:\n  \u2022 target_quantum: map input dual-rail qubit on [0,1] to output on [2,3].  \n  \u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3).  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [4] (the non\u2010Gaussian ancilla).  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] (prevent direct SPDC across nonadjacent modes).  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes ([5\u20138]).  \n  \u2022 linear_optics: static interferometer mixing [1,2,4,5,6,7,8], parameterized by {\u03b8\u1d62,\u03d5\u1d62}.  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that signals successful teleportation.  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancilla detectors.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 Chain more hops by adding SPDC links and ancillas, each variationally optimized.  \n  \u2013 Compare against fixed Bell\u2010swap teleportation under loss and noise.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational photonic networks that fuse continuous\u2010variable resources (squeezed vacua) with non\u2010Gaussian catalysis for high\u2010fidelity quantum\u2010network transformations."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nCorner-Protected Bell\u2013Swap Teleportation in a 3\u00d73 Photonic Quadruple-Insulator Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a 3\u00d73 photonic quadruple-insulator network to teleport quantum information between modes 0 and 8 via two successive Bell-state measurements, heralding the target Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2088 (i.e. \u201c00\u201d\u2013\u201c11\u201d) through intermediate swaps on modes (1,4) and (4,7). By toggling between the \u201ctrivial\u201d edge-bond connectivity (sources on outer edges) and the \u201ctopological\u201d central-plaquette connectivity (sources on interior bonds), we compare heralded success probabilities\u2014equivalent to effective teleportation fidelities\u2014to directly probe the corner-mode protection predicted for higher-order photonic quadruple insulators.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. ancB1, ancB2, ancD1, ancD2 indicates successful percolation  \n  \u2022 number_resolving: True on all ancillas  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 Extend to larger lattices (M\u00d7N graphs) with more boosters.  \n  \u2013 Explore non-Gaussian percolation thresholds vs. Gaussian limits.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational, catalysis-enhanced network primitives in photonic quantum inputs.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Input qubit modes: [0,1]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla (SPDC source): modes [2,3]  \n  Vacuum ancillas: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. We start with two imperfect SPDC EPR links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133), plus a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135). All six modes (1,2,4,5) are mixed in a static, parameterized linear-optics network (beam-splitter angles \u03b8\u1d62 and phase shifts \u03d5\u1d62), together with two vacuum ancillas (modes 6,7). A specific click pattern on the four ancilla detectors heralds a near-ideal Bell pair on A\u2013D. A classical optimizer variationally adjusts {\u03b8\u1d62,\u03d5\u1d62} to maximize the heralded fidelity (or negativity) of the resulting |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 state between modes 0 and 3.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n SPDC sources:  \n   Link A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n   Link C\u2013D: modes [2\u20133]  \n   Ancilla SV:  modes [4\u20135]  \n\n              \u2198            \u2199  \n Parameterized interferometer on modes [1,2,4,5] + vacuum ancillas [6,7]  \n              \u2193  \n Detectors: [A_out=0], [D_out=3], anc1=4, anc2=5, anc3=6, anc4=7  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration:\n\n\u2022 target_quantum: ['00','11'] on output modes [0,3]  \n\u2022 probabilistic photon-pair sources on (0,1), (2,3), (4,5)  (the last = squeezed-vacuum ancilla)  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2  (vacuum ancillas modes 6,7)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: []  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]  (no direct SPDC linking non-adjacent nodes)  \n\u2022 linear_optics: all static beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes [1,2,4,5,6,7], parameterized by external variables {\u03b8\u1d62,\u03d5\u1d62}  \n\u2022 number_resolving: True on ancilla detectors  \n\u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that heralds successful swapping  \n\u2022 Classical outer loop: tunes {\u03b8\u1d62,\u03d5\u1d62} to maximize A\u2013D entanglement.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2013 No prior Pytheus experiment injects a squeezed-vacuum ancilla into the swap measurement.  \n\u2013 Embeds a true variational quantum-algorithm layer (classical optimizer over LOQC parameters) around an entanglement-swapping primitive.  \n\u2013 Goes beyond fixed Bell measurements to discover, via optimization, the best \u201cnon-Gaussian\u2013assisted\u201d joint measurement.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus:\n\u2013 Uses only SPDC pair sources (abstract two-mode sources), static linear-optics, vacuum modes, and number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n\u2013 The variational part (parameter tuning) lives entirely outside Pytheus\u2019s static circuit search.  \n\u2013 No dynamic feedback control, no homodyne or displacements, no cavities\u2014fully compatible with Pytheus.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2013 Chain N such squeez\u00aded-ancilla swap nodes to build a variational repeater line.  \n\u2013 Replace the single ancilla SPDC by higher-gain squeezed vacua or multiple ancillas to study non-Gaussian boosting.  \n\u2013 Benchmark against standard entanglement-swapping over lossy SPDC links to quantify the \u201csqueeze-boost\u201d advantage."
}

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. ancillas, heralded by photon detection.  \n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus\u2010compatibility check:  \n    a) Similar to known variational\u2010Bell\u2010measurements for swapping\u2014runs risk of duplication.  \n    b) Requires teleportation of arbitrary unknown states and CV recovery (displacements), not easily captured by Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV framework.  \n    c) No prior purification experiments in the list; uses only SPDC pair sources, linear optics, vacuum ancillas, photon detection, and a classical outer loop to tune beam\u2010splitters\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  Step 3: Select (c) as the most promising idea.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because entanglement purification with squeezed\u2010vacuum EPR links has never been cast as a variational network design problem; instead of fixed parity\u2010check circuits, one optimizes a family of linear\u2010optics purification unitaries to maximize final Bell\u2010state fidelity.  \n
