{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Implemented in the PytHeus framework, our scheme uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, tunable beam-splitter reflectivities, ancilla detectors, and removed_connection constraints to enforce the binary-tree topology without dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated-Photonic Entanglement\u2010Dimension Splitting Supermap via Optical Metasurface  \n\nAbstract:  We propose an on-chip supermap that passively converts a single d\u00b2-dimensional Bell link between nodes A and B into two independent d-dimensional Bell links A\u2013C and B\u2013D, targeting the coherent \u201cdimension splitting\u201d of entanglement without active feed-forward.  The scheme employs two probabilistic photon-pair sources, one ancilla photon, a static (d\u00b2+1)\u00d7(d\u00b2+1) metasurface multiport and number-resolving heralding detectors, and is fully optimizable within the PyTheus framework as a new resource-multiplexing primitive for quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. Upon a specific four-click detection pattern, the unmeasured remote modes collapse into the target qubit Bell state, achieving the conversion from two qutrit Bell pairs to one qubit Bell pair.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer with Single-Photon Ancilla\n\nAbstract: We present a purely network-primitive linear-optical scheme that employs a single ancillary photon and a static 4-mode interferometer\u2014decomposed into three optimized beam splitters\u2014to unambiguously identify all four Bell states (\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b) of two abstract dual-rail qubits with a post-selected success rate of 62.5% and perfect conditional fidelity. By directing the four outputs into number-resolving detectors and post-selecting on exactly one click, the target Bell projection is implemented without polarization encoding, feed-forward, or extra resources, enabling higher-rate entanglement swapping and repeater protocols.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Linear-Optical Four-Body Parity-Phase Gate for Digital Kitaev Hamiltonian Simulation\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe introduce a static, post-selected linear-optical gadget that implements the four-qubit parity-phase unitaries U\u2093=exp(\u2212i\u03c0X\u2081X\u2082X\u2083X\u2084/4) and U_z=exp(\u2212i\u03c0Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084/4) corresponding to the star and plaquette terms of the Kitaev Hamiltonian via Bell-pair ancillas, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number\u2013resolving detectors. Concatenating U\u2093 then U_z in a single heralded Trotter step realizes one digital interaction unitary e^{\u2212i\u03b8H_Kitaev} on four photonic qubits, enabling network-based simulation of topological codes without requiring state generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Photonic Projector onto Two-Qubit Heisenberg Ground-State Manifolds\n\nAbstract: We present a heralded, reconfigurable two-qubit linear-optical module that postselectively projects arbitrary photon-encoded qubit inputs onto the ground-state manifold of the tunable two-body Heisenberg Hamiltonian H(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8\u2009(\u03c3\u2093\u03c3\u2093+\u03c3_y\u03c3_y)+sin \u03b8\u2009\u03c3_z\u03c3_z\u2014realizing the antisymmetric singlet subspace at \u03b8=0 or the symmetric triplet subspace at \u03b8=\u03c0/2. By using two ancilla photons, a four-mode interferometer with adjustable internal phases, and number-resolving detectors to signal success, the device achieves the target projection and can be chained via entanglement swapping to simulate and distribute spin-chain ground-state correlations across a fully programmable photonic network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nCorner-Protected Bell\u2013Swap Teleportation in a 3\u00d73 Photonic Quadruple-Insulator Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a 3\u00d73 photonic quadruple-insulator network to teleport quantum information between modes 0 and 8 via two successive Bell-state measurements, heralding the target Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2088 (i.e. \u201c00\u201d\u2013\u201c11\u201d) through intermediate swaps on modes (1,4) and (4,7). By toggling between the \u201ctrivial\u201d edge-bond connectivity (sources on outer edges) and the \u201ctopological\u201d central-plaquette connectivity (sources on interior bonds), we compare heralded success probabilities\u2014equivalent to effective teleportation fidelities\u2014to directly probe the corner-mode protection predicted for higher-order photonic quadruple insulators.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. To be novel at the PRL\u2010level, you must propose a measurement supermap or routing primitive that cannot be reduced to parameter tuning of an existing butterfly code or squeezed-ancilla swap network\u2014e.g., an indefinite\u2010order coding protocol, a new multi-photon catalysis effect, or a fundamentally different non-Gaussian network operation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed-Vacuum\u2013Assisted Photonic Telecloning  \nGoal: Teleclone an unknown dual-rail qubit prepared by two single-photon emitters at modes A0/A1 (nodes 0,1) into two approximate copies on modes B0/B1 (nodes 2,3) and C0/C1 (nodes 4,5), using two imperfect SPDC EPR links (A\u2194B and A\u2194C) and one squeezed-vacuum ancilla to boost fidelity. The telecloning node mixes incoming modes [1,2,4] and the squeezervac ancilla mode [6] plus vacuum ancillas [7,8], in a static linear-optics circuit. A heralded click pattern on detectors [7,8] projects the outputs. A **classical variational optimizer** tunes all beam-splitter angles and phase shifts in that static circuit to maximize the average clone fidelity to the original qubit.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters: [0,1]               \u2190 Input dual-rail qubit  \n  SPDC EPR link A\u2013B: modes [0\u20132]  \n  SPDC EPR link A\u2013C: modes [1\u20134]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla SPDC: modes [6\u20139]  \n             \u2198      \u2199     \u2198    \u2199  \n  Static interferometer on modes [1,2,4,6] + vacuum ancillas [7,8]  \n             \u2193  \n  Detectors:  \n    Outputs: B0=2, B1=3    (first clone)  \n             C0=4, C1=5    (second clone)  \n    Heralding: anc1=7, anc2=8  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements:\n  description: \"Variational squeezed\u2010vacuum telecloning\"\n  foldername:   \"VarSV_Teleclone\"\n  edges_tried:  30\n  ftol:         1e-06\n  loss_func:    \"cr\"\n  optimizer:    \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples:      10\n  target_quantum: [\"1001\",\"0110\"]  \n    \u2013 maps input |10\u27e9_{0,1}\u2192|10\u27e9_{2,3}\u2297|10\u27e9_{4,5} and |01\u27e9_{0,1}\u2192|01\u27e9_{2,3}\u2297|01\u27e9_{4,5}  \n  single_emitters: [0,1]\n  probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources: [(0,2),(1,4),(6,9)]\n  removed_connections: [[0,4],[1,2]]\n  num_anc: 2\n  vacuum ancillas: [7,8]\n  number_resolving: true\n  heralding_out: null\n  anc_detectors: [7,8]\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 Chain multiple telecloning nodes to build tree\u2010like variational network coders.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010off between squeezervac strength and clone fidelity under realistic losses.  \n  \u2013 Establishes a new class of **variational, CV-assisted network transformations**, here applied to telecloning, fully within Pytheus\u2019s discrete\u2010photon, linear\u2010optics, heralded framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This variational telecloning scheme merely wraps the known 1\u21922 linear\u2010optical telecloning primitive (e.g. \u201cHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning\u201d in the ensemble) with a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla and a classical optimizer tuning beam splitters and phases. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. tune intermediate joint\u2010measurement unitaries (beam\u2010splitters and phases) via a classical optimizer to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement.\n    2) A variational teleportation of a qubit encoded in the even/odd photon\u2010number subspace of a squeezed\u2010vacuum cat state; optimize the linear\u2010optics recovery circuit to maximize teleportation fidelity.\n    3) A measurement\u2010based cluster network built from offline\u2010generated squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas, where one variationally chooses homodyne measurement angles to enact a family of two\u2010mode gates between distant nodes. \n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus\u2010compatibility:\n    1) Novel: merges VQA and entanglement swapping in a repeater motif; Pytheus can handle probabilistic pair sources and optimize static linear\u2010optics networks, no dynamic feedback. \n    2) Generates non\u2010Gaussian cat states and teleports them: violates the \u201cno state\u2010generation\u201d rule and requires CV/homodyne beyond Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV framework.\n    3) Requires homodyne detection and continuous variable post\u2010processing, not supported by Pytheus\u2019s abstract qudit-and-photon model.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 1 as the most promising: a variational entanglement\u2010swapping repeater using SPDC sources.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it casts the design of an entanglement\u2010swapping repeater\u2014traditionally fixed by Bell\u2010measurement bases\u2014as a variational algorithm over linear\u2010optics parameters, optimizing end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement of two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum links.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n    - It only uses probabilistic two-mode squeezed-vacuum pair sources (SPDC) encoded abstractly as photon-pair sources.\n    - It relies on static beam\u2010splitters, phase\u2010shifters, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capability.\n    - The classical outer loop that adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles is external to Pytheus; Pytheus searches for the best fixed network given those angles.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Swapping Repeater Network  \nWe aim to distribute high\u2010fidelity Bell entanglement between two distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by connecting them with two two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (SPDC) sources at links A\u2013B and C\u2013D, and performing an intermediate, parameterized joint measurement at nodes B (mode 1) and C (mode 2). A classical optimizer variationally adjusts the joint\u2010measurement linear\u2010optics network (beam-splitter angles and phase shifts) to maximize the entanglement (e.g. negativity or fidelity to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) between A and D, heralded by a specific click pattern on the ancillary detectors.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]  \n (2,3) (default if single_emitters is empty)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]  \n      \u2013 ensures no direct source spans nonadjacent modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify the click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 used to herald successful swapping  \n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics network between modes [1,2,4,5,6,7] is parameterized by a set of beam-splitter angles {\u03b8_i,\u03d5_i}, subject to external classical optimization  \n  \u2022 Use number\u2010resolving detectors  \n\nGeneralization and scientific impact:\n  \u2013 Extends standard entanglement swapping into a variational repeater design, potentially improving robustness to realistic SPDC imperfections.  \n  \u2013 Can be scaled to N links (multiple intermediate nodes) The most promising and genuinely new concept is to **enhance entanglement swapping by injecting an extra squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla** at the swapping node and to treat the static linear\u2010optics measurement as a **variational supermap**.  This goes beyond merely tuning a Bell\u2010measurement: it uses a non\u2010Gaussian resource (a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla) to break the usual Gaussian limits of swapping, and employs an external optimizer to find the optimal interferometer parameters.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed\u2010Vacuum\u2010Assisted Entanglement Swapping  \nGoal: Distribute a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by entanglement swapping of two imperfect EPR links (SPDC sources on 0\u20131 and 2\u20133), **enhanced** by a third SPDC\u2010generated squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla. One mode of the ancilla (mode 4) enters the joint\u2010measurement interferometer at the repeater node (mixing with modes 1 and 2 and with vacuum ancillas), the other ancilla mode (5) is measured. A classical variational loop tunes all beam\u2010splitter angles and phase shifts in this static interferometer to **maximize the heralded fidelity** of the final two\u2010mode state on nodes [0,3] to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n  SPDC sources:  \n    Link A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    Link C\u2013D: modes [2\u20133]  \n    Squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla: modes [4\u20135]  \n          \u2198     \u2199  \n  Variational interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [6,7]  \n          \u2193  \n  Detectors: [A_out=0],[D_out=3],[anc_sv=5],[vac1=6],[vac2=7]\n\nPytheus Configuration Snippet:\n```\n{\n  description: \"Variational squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010assisted entanglement swapping\",\n  foldername: \"VarSV_ES\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 3,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: (0,1), (2,3), (4,5),\n  single_emitters: [],\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[1,3],[2,3],[3,4]],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null,\n  anc_detectors: [5,6,7]\n}\n```\n\nKey Features:\n- Uses **three** SPDC pair\u2010sources: two build the initial links, one provides the squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla.\n- The **static** linear\u2010optics network at the repeater node mixes the ancilla mode with the two link modes and vacuum ancillas; all beam\u2010splitters and phases are **variational parameters** set by an outer optimizer.\n- Herald success by a click pattern on the three ancilla detectors; the averaged output on [0,3] approximates the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with maximal fidelity.\n- Fully within Pytheus\u2019s DV\u2013photon-pair, linear-optics, number-resolving framework; no cavities, feedback, or homodyne detection.\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n- **Multi\u2010hop extension**: chain such squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010enhanced swap modules to build a variational repeater.\n- **Resource trade\u2010off studies**: how much ancilla squeezing vs. network depth is needed under realistic loss.\n- Opens a new class of **variational non-Gaussian supermaps** in photonic quantum networks, blending continuous-variable resources with variational algorithm design.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core concept\u2014injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla into the swap node and tuning a static interferometer to boost heralded Bell fidelity\u2014duplicates the ensemble\u2019s squeezed-reservoir swapping scheme.     "output": "Here is a fresh target that (i) stays entirely within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox (SPDC pair\u2010sources, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors), (ii) is a genuine quantum\u2010network transformation (entanglement swapping), and (iii) marries a variational quantum\u2010algorithm layer with a squeezed\u2010vacuum resource in a way not yet explored:\n\nDescription:  \nVariational Squeezed-Vacuum-Enabled Near-Deterministic Entanglement Swapping  \n\nGoal:  \nTake two imperfect SPDC\u2010generated EPR links, A\u2013B and C\u2013D, and perform an \u201cenhanced\u201d entanglement swap at the middle (B\u2013C) that\u2014by injecting a third SPDC squeezed-vacuum ancilla and mixing it with the link modes\u2014boosts the heralding success probability for a high-fidelity Bell state on A\u2013D. A classical optimizer loops over the beam-splitter angles and phase shifts in the static B\u2013C interferometer to maximize the swap success probability (subject to a fidelity threshold), effectively turning the swap node into a variational supermap.\n\nGeneral schematic (modes top\u2192bottom, left\u2192right):\n\n  SPDC links:\n    A\u2013B : modes [0\u20131]  \n    C\u2013D : modes [2\u20133]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla: modes [4\u20135]  \n                      \n        \u2198         \u2199  \n    Variational interferometer at B\u2013C on modes [1,2,4]  \n        + vacuum ancillas [6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n  Detectors:  \n     A_out=0   D_out=3   anc1=5   anc2=6   anc3=7  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration parameters:\n\n```\ndescription: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum\u2013enabled near-deterministic entanglement swapping\"\nfoldername:  \"VarSV_NDet_ES\"\nedges_tried: 30\nftol:        1e-06\nloss_func:   \"cr\"\noptimizer:   \"L-BFGS-B\"\nsamples:     10\n\n# We have three SPDC sources: two build the initial EPR links; one gives the squeezed-vacuum ancilla.\nprobabilistic photon-pair sources: [(0,1), (2,3), (4,5)]\n\n# No single_emitters needed\nsingle_emitters: []\n\n# Prevent any direct SPDC link skipping the center\nremoved_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]\n\n# We mix modes [1,2,4] + 2 vacuum ancillas [6,7] in a static LO network \n# whose beam-splitters & phases are the variational parameters.\nnum_anc: 2                 \n# Output target is the Bell basis on modes [0,3]\ntarget_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"]\n\n# Herald success when ancilla detectors click in a specified pattern.\nnumber_resolving: true\nheralding_out:   null      \nanc_detectors:   [5,6,7]\n```\n\nHow it works:  \n\u2013 You begin with two noisy EPR pairs on (0,1) and (2,3).  \n\u2013 A third SPDC source on (4,5) provides a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla.  \n\u2013 At the swap node you feed modes 1,2,4 plus two vacuum ancillas (6,7) into a static interferometer  \n  (composed of beam-splitters and phase shifters).  \n\u2013 The classical outer loop picks all internal angles {\u03b8\u1d62,\u03d5\u1d62} to **maximize** the probability that a particular click pattern on ancillas [5,6,7] heralds the creation of |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on [0,3], subject to a fidelity constraint (e.g. F\u22650.9).  \n\nGenerality & Impact:  \n\u2013 This protocol elevates the entanglement-swap node from a 50%-max probabilistic projector to a **tunable**, near-deterministic supermap by leveraging a squeezed-vacuum resource.  \n\u2013 One can chain N of these nodes into a full repeater\u2014and variationally optimize the entire repeater segment-by-segment.  \n\u2013 Opens a new avenue: instead of fixed Bell measurements, one uses continuous-variable ancillas plus variational design to push heralding rates toward unity under realistic noise.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:  \nAlthough ancilla-assisted swaps and variational Bell-measurements have been studied separately, nobody has yet cast **entanglement swapping** itself as a **variational, squeezed-vacuum\u2013enabled near-deterministic supermap**. This moves beyond simply tuning a Bell-swap ansatz\u2014here the ancilla is a genuine two-mode squeezer, and the optimizer shapes a multi-mode LO network to outperform Gaussian-only swap limits.  \n\nWhy it fits Pytheus:  \nPytheus already supports probabilistic pair sources (SPDC links and squeezers abstractly), static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors, and abstract target\u2010state fidelity metrics. The \u201cvariational\u201d part lives entirely in an external classical loop that picks beam-splitter angles\u2014the search for a static circuit template given those angles is exactly what Pytheus does best."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. optimize the linear\u2010optics recovery circuit to maximize teleportation fidelity.\n    3) A measurement\u2010based cluster network built from offline\u2010generated squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas, where one variationally chooses homodyne measurement angles to enact a family of two\u2010mode gates between distant nodes. \n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus\u2010compatibility:\n    1) Novel: merges VQA and entanglement swapping in a repeater motif; Pytheus can handle probabilistic pair sources and optimize static linear\u2010optics networks, no dynamic feedback. \n    2) Generates non\u2010Gaussian cat states and teleports them: violates the \u201cno state\u2010generation\u201d rule and requires CV/homodyne beyond Pytheus\u2019s abstract DV framework.\n    3) Requires homodyne detection and continuous variable post\u2010processing, not supported by Pytheus\u2019s abstract qudit-and-photon model.\n  Step 3: Pick idea 1 as the most promising: a variational entanglement\u2010swapping repeater using SPDC sources.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it casts the design of an entanglement\u2010swapping repeater\u2014traditionally fixed by Bell\u2010measurement bases\u2014as a variational algorithm over linear\u2010optics parameters, optimizing end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement of two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum links.\n  Step 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n    - It only uses probabilistic two-mode squeezed-vacuum pair sources (SPDC) encoded abstractly as photon-pair sources.\n    - It relies on static beam\u2010splitters, phase\u2010shifters, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capability.\n    - The classical outer loop that adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles is external to Pytheus; Pytheus searches for the best fixed network given those angles.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Swapping Repeater Network  \nWe aim to distribute high\u2010fidelity Bell entanglement between two distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by connecting them with two two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (SPDC) sources at links A\u2013B and C\u2013D, and performing an intermediate, parameterized joint measurement at nodes B (mode 1) and C (mode 2). A classical optimizer variationally adjusts the joint\u2010measurement linear\u2010optics network (beam-splitter angles and phase shifts) to maximize the entanglement (e.g. negativity or fidelity to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) between A and D, heralded by a specific click pattern on the ancillary detectors.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC sources: [0\u20131]   [2\u20133]  \n The most promising and genuinely new concept is to **enhance entanglement swapping by injecting an extra squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla** at the swapping node and to treat the static linear\u2010optics measurement as a **variational supermap**.  This goes beyond merely tuning a Bell\u2010measurement: it uses a non\u2010Gaussian resource (a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla) to break the usual Gaussian limits of swapping, and employs an external optimizer to find the optimal interferometer parameters.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed\u2010Vacuum\u2010Assisted Entanglement Swapping  \nGoal: Distribute a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by entanglement swapping of two imperfect EPR links (SPDC sources on 0\u20131 and 2\u20133), **enhanced** by a third SPDC\u2010generated squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla. One mode of the ancilla (mode 4) enters the joint\u2010measurement interferometer at the repeater node (mixing with modes 1 and 2 and with vacuum ancillas), the other ancilla mode (5) is measured. A classical variational loop tunes all beam\u2010splitter angles and phase shifts in this static interferometer to **maximize the heralded fidelity** of the final two\u2010mode state on nodes [0,3] to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n  SPDC sources:  \n    Link A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    Link C\u2013D: modes [2\u20133]  \n    Squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla: modes [4\u20135]  \n          \u2198     \u2199  \n  Variational interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [6,7]  \n          \u2193  \n  Detectors: [A_out=0],[D_out=3],[anc_sv=5],[vac1=6],[vac2=7]\n\nPytheus Configuration Snippet:\n```\n{\n  description: \"Variational squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010assisted entanglement swapping\",\n  foldername: \"VarSV_ES\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 3,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: (0,1), (2,3), (4,5),\n  single_emitters: [],\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[1,3],[2,3],[3,4]],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null,\n  anc_detectors: [5,6,7]\n}\n```\n\nKey Features:\n- Uses **three** SPDC pair\u2010sources: two build the initial links, one provides the squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla.\n- The **static** linear\u2010optics network at the repeater node mixes the ancilla mode with the two link modes and vacuum ancillas; all beam\u2010splitters and phases are **variational parameters** set by an outer optimizer.\n- Herald success by a click pattern on the three ancilla detectors; the averaged output on [0,3] approximates the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with maximal fidelity.\n- Fully within Pytheus\u2019s DV\u2013photon-pair, linear-optics, number-resolving framework; no cavities, feedback, or homodyne detection.\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n- **Multi\u2010hop extension**: chain such squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010enhanced swap modules to build a variational repeater.\n- **Resource trade\u2010off studies**: how much ancilla squeezing vs. network depth is needed under realistic loss.\n- Opens a new class of **variational non-Gaussian supermaps** in photonic quantum networks, blending continuous-variable resources with variational algorithm design.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core concept\u2014injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla into the swap node and tuning a static interferometer to boost heralded Bell fidelity\u2014duplicates the ensemble\u2019s squeezed-reservoir swapping scheme. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nI\u2019ve identified a genuinely new network\u2010transformation primitive that sits outside all existing Pytheus experiments: a **variational, squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2013assisted entanglement router**.  It takes multiple SPDC EPR links feeding a central node, injects a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla there, and uses a static, parameterized linear\u2010optics interferometer to **route** a Bell pair on demand between any two chosen leaves\u2014tuned by a classical optimizer.  This is not mere swapping or teleportation, but a programmable entanglement\u2010switch in one static circuit, combining a continuous\u2010variable resource and a variational quantum algorithm.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed-Vacuum-Assisted Entanglement Router in a Star Topology  \nGoal:  Given four imperfect EPR links (two\u2010mode squeezed vacua via SPDC) that connect outer nodes A, B, C, D to a central router X, plus one extra two\u2010mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla at X, design a **static** linear-optics circuit at X whose beam-splitter angles and phase-shifts are chosen by an outer classical optimizer.  Upon heralding a specific click pattern on the ancilla detectors, the circuit will deliver a high-fidelity Bell pair between any user-selected pair of outer nodes (e.g. A & C or B & D).  \n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\n SPDC EPR links:  \n   A\u2013X: modes [0\u20134]  \n   B\u2013X: modes [1\u20135]  \n   C\u2013X: modes [2\u20136]  \n   D\u2013X: modes [3\u20137]  \n Squeezed-vacuum ancilla: modes [8\u20139]  \n Vacuum ancillas at X: modes [10\u201313]  \n\n       \u2198                   \u2199  \n  Parameterized interferometer at X on modes [4,5,6,7,8,10,11,12,13]  \n       \u2193  \n  Detectors:  \n    Outputs: detA=0, detB=1, detC=2, detD=3  \n    Heralding: anc1=9, anc2=10, anc3=11, anc4=12, anc5=13  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration snippet:\n{\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum\u2013assisted entanglement router\",\n  foldername:   \"VarSV_EntRouter\",\n  edges_tried:  40,\n  ftol:         1e-06,\n  loss_func:    \"cr\",\n  optimizer:    \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:      10,\n  num_anc:      5,                        # ancilla detectors [9\u201313]\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],            # on whichever two outer modes we route\n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: [\n    (0,4),(1,5),(2,6),(3,7),(8,9)\n  ],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,5],[0,6],[0,7],\n    [1,4],[1,6],[1,7],\n    [2,4],[2,5],[2,7],\n    [3,4],[3,5],[3,6]\n  ],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null,                    # define per-pair heralding patterns\n  anc_detectors: [9,10,11,12,13]\n}\n\nWhy this is novel and interesting:\n\u2013 It **routes entanglement** on demand in one static LO circuit, not just swaps or teleports along fixed links.  \n\u2013 It injects a **continuous-variable resource** (a squeezed-vacuum ancilla) into a discrete-variable network to exceed Gaussian routing limits.  \n\u2013 A classical outer loop tunes all beam-splitters & phases **variationally**, opening the door to optimized network coding and entanglement distribution.  \n\u2013 Fully implementable in Pytheus: uses SPDC pair sources, static beam-splitter/phase networks, vacuum ancillas, number-resolving detectors, and no dynamic feedback.  \n\u2013 Scales to larger star or tree topologies by adding EPR links and ancillas.\n\nThis defines a new class of **variational network primitives**\u2014programmable entanglement switches\u2014that blend squeezed-vacuum resources with linear-optics, meeting all the provided constraints."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Programmable Photonic Teleportation Router for Three Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a three-input/three-output linear-optical network\u2014the Programmable Photonic Teleportation Router for Three Qubits\u2014that, under a classical \u201cprogram\u201d of three static phase-shifter settings, permutes and teleports three unknown qubits from senders Alice\u2081, Alice\u2082, Alice\u2083 onto receivers Bob\u208d\u03c0(1)\u208e, Bob\u208d\u03c0(2)\u208e, Bob\u208d\u03c0(3)\u208e for any \u03c0\u2208S\u2083. By combining three probabilistic EPR photon-pair sources, a programmable six-mode interferometer, and post-selected Bell measurements, this novel quantum-network primitive realizes fully programmable routing of unknown qubits without dynamic feed-forward or cavity resources.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nReusable Catalytic Entanglement Swapping for Enhanced EPR Link Generation\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe demonstrate a linear-optical \u201ccatalytic\u201d entanglement-swapping protocol that employs a permanent EPR pair (the X\u2032\u2013Y\u2032 catalyst) to boost the long-term entanglement generation rate between nodes A and B without consuming the catalyst link. By mixing three probabilistic photon-pair sources in a passive six-mode interferometer and number-resolving detection, we herald simultaneous Bell pairs on modes [0,1] (A\u2013B) and [6,7] (X\u2032\u2013Y\u2032), thereby achieving repeated high-rate entanglement between A and B while preserving the reusable resource link.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nDirect Single-Shot Measurement of the Second R\u00e9nyi OTOC in a Four-Site Atom Array via Photonic Interferometry  \n\nAbstract:  \nWe propose a fully linear-optical protocol to measure the second R\u00e9nyi out-of-time-ordered correlator O\u2082(t)=\u27e8W\u2081(t)V\u2084W\u2081(t)V\u2084\u27e9 on a four-qubit atom array in a single shot. By encoding each \u201catom\u201d qubit as a dual-rail single photon, inserting Pauli-X operations through local phase flips, and deploying two Bell-pair ancillas for parallel swap-test subcircuits, a Pythues-optimized 4\u00d74 interferometer implements U(t) and U\u2020(t) and heralds the OTOC value via zero-click correlations on number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node. Similar catalysis\u2010and\u2010parity\u2010check purification schemes (including squeezed\u2010reservoir boosters and parity\u2010swap repeater nodes) already appear in the ensemble; simply tuning beam\u2010splitter angles and phases does not meet the bar for a fundamentally new PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea is too close to existing squeezed\u2010ancilla purification and parity\u2010check protocols (e.g. squeezed\u2010reservoir swapping, measurement\u2010induced parity\u2010swap repeaters). To be novel, you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian measurement supermap or resource\u2014one that cannot be reduced to classical parameter tuning of known distillation circuits.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed-Vacuum-Assisted Entanglement Router  \nGoal:\nGiven four imperfect SPDC-generated EPR links connecting a central router node X to outer nodes A, B, C, D, and a single two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla at X, design a static linear-optics circuit at X whose beam-splitter angles and phase-shifts are chosen by a classical variational algorithm so that, upon the correct heralding click pattern on the ancilla and vacuum-ancilla detectors, any two selected outer nodes (e.g. A & C or B & D) emerge sharing a high-fidelity Bell pair.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\n SPDC EPR links:  \n   A\u2013X: modes [0\u20134]  \n   B\u2013X: modes [1\u20135]  \n   C\u2013X: modes [2\u20136]  \n   D\u2013X: modes [3\u20137]  \n Squeezed-vacuum ancilla: modes [8\u20139]  \n Vacuum ancillas at X: modes [10\u201313]  \n           \u2198                 \u2199  \nParametrized interferometer on modes [4,5,6,7,8,10,11,12,13]  \n           \u2193  \nDetectors:  \n  Outputs: detA=0, detB=1, detC=2, detD=3  \n  Heralding: anc1=9, anc2=10, anc3=11, anc4=12, anc5=13  \n\nKey Pytheus configuration:\n{\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum\u2013assisted entanglement router\",\n  foldername: \"VarSV_EntRouter\",\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 5,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],      # For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"variational quantum algorithm\" and \"squeezed vacuum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Moves beyond fixed swapping circuits to a resource\u2010adaptive network code.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus: \n    \u2022 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources = abstract probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources.  \n    \u2022 Static interferometer on incoming modes + vacuum ancillas, parameterized by angles/ phases (optimized externally).  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback; all optics are static.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Entanglement\u2010Routing Switch in a Photonic Mesh  \nGoal: Given four SPDC\u2010generated EPR links connecting a central node X to four outer nodes A, B, C, D, design a parameterized linear\u2010optics \u201crouter\u201d at X that\u2014upon a chosen heralding\u2010click pattern\u2014delivers a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between any two selected outer nodes (e.g. A & C). A classical optimizer variationally tunes the beam\u2010splitter angles and phase shifts in X\u2019s interferometer to maximize the output entanglement for each target pairing.\n\nVisualization (modes unintended cross\u2010links  \n  \u2022 num_anc: 4 vacuum\u2010ancilla modes ([8\u201311])  \n  \u2022 heralding_out: specify a particular click pattern on anc1\u2013anc4 that heralds successful routing  \n  \u2022 linear\u2010optics network on modes [4\u20137,8\u201311] parameterized by a vector of beam\u2010splitter angles {\u03b8_i} and phases {\u03d5_i}  \n    \u2013 These parameters are different heralding patterns or retraining parameters, the same hardware routes entanglement between any chosen pair of end\u2010nodes\u2014an all\u2010optical entanglement \u201cswitch.\u201d  \n A classical optimizer variationally tunes the interferometer\u2019s beam-splitter angles and phase shifts to maximize the average discrimination fidelity (or success probability) over the four Bell inputs.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  Input qubit modes: [0,1]  \n  Squeezed-vacuum ancilla (SPDC source): modes [2,3]  \n  Vacuum ancillas: modes [4,5,6,7]  \n            \u2193  \n  Parameterized linear-optics network on modes [0\u20137]  \n            \u2193  \n  Detectors: [det0=0],[det1=1],[det2=2],[det3=3],[anc4=4],[anc5=5],[anc6=6],[anc7=7]\n\nConfiguration for Pytheus:\n  description: \"Variational squeezed-vacuum-assisted Bell-state analyzer\"\n  foldername: \"VQA_SV_BSA\"\n  target_quantum: ['10000000','01000000','00100000','00010000']\n    \u2013 maps the four Bell input states to four orthogonal single-click patterns on detectors 0\u20133  \n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: on mode pairs (0,1) (the input Bell pair) and (2,3) (the squeezed-vacuum ancilla)\n  num_anc: 4\n  single_emitters: []\n  removed_connections: []\n  bursts_thr: 0.0\n  edges_tried: 50\n  ftol: 1e-6\n  loss_func: \"cr\"\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples: 10\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1]\n  number_resolving: True\n  heralding_out: None (the analyzer succeeds when exactly one click occurs in detectors 0\u20133 and none in 4\u20137)\n  topopt: None\n  seed: None\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n  \u2013 External variational loop can re-optimize for different noise models or detector efficiencies.  \n  \u2013 Can be extended to higher-dimensional Bell-state analysis using multi-mode squeezed vacua.  \n  \u2013 Opens a new class of variational measurement tasks in quantum networks, leveraging continuous-variable ancillas in an all-linear-optics, discrete-detection setting.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core concept overlaps the ensemble\u2019s variational squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell\u2010POVM. Feasible: uses only SPDC pair\u2010sources, single\u2010photon emitters, static linear optics, vacuum ancillas, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The outer classical loop adjusts beam\u2010splitter angles\u2014outside Pytheus.\n  Step 3: Select idea (c).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it transforms the standard two\u2010link entanglement\u2010swapping teleportation into a variational \u201cphoton\u2010catalyzed\u201d network: injecting non\u2010Gaussian ancillas at the repeater node and optimizing its static interferometer to maximize end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation fidelity, instead of using a fixed Bell\u2010swap.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n    \u2022 Two SPDC links are abstract probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources on (0,1) and (2,3).  \n    \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitters at node B (mode 4) supply the non\u2010Gaussian ancilla.  \n    \u2022 Static linear\u2010optics on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [5\u20138], all describable by beam\u2010splitters and phases.  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors herald successes.  \n    \u2022 An external classical optimizer sets the beam\u2010splitter angles and phases\u2014Pytheus only needs to search the static circuit form.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Photon\u2010Catalyzed Dual\u2010Hop Teleportation  \nGoal: Teleport an unknown dual\u2010rail qubit held in modes A\u2080/A\u2081 (nodes 0,1) to modes C\u2080/C\u2081 (nodes 2,3) across two imperfect SPDC EPR links (A\u2192B and B\u2192C) by injecting a single\u2010photon ancilla at the intermediate node B (mode 4). A parametrized static interferometer at B mixes the two incoming EPR modes and the ancilla (plus vacuum ancillas), and a specific heralding click pattern projects modes A and C into the teleported state. The most promising and genuinely new concept is to **enhance entanglement swapping by injecting an extra squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla** at the swapping node and to treat the static linear\u2010optics measurement as a **variational supermap**.  This goes beyond merely tuning a Bell\u2010measurement: it uses a non\u2010Gaussian resource (a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla) to break the usual Gaussian limits of swapping, and employs an external optimizer to find the optimal interferometer parameters.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nDescription: Variational Squeezed\u2010Vacuum\u2010Assisted Entanglement Swapping  \nGoal: Distribute a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between distant modes A (node 0) and D (node 3) by entanglement swapping of two imperfect EPR links (SPDC sources on 0\u20131 and 2\u20133), **enhanced** by a third SPDC\u2010generated squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla. One mode of the ancilla (mode 4) enters the joint\u2010measurement interferometer at the repeater node (mixing with modes 1 and 2 and with vacuum ancillas), the other ancilla mode (5) is measured. A classical variational loop tunes all beam\u2010splitter angles and phase shifts in this static interferometer to **maximize the heralded fidelity** of the final two\u2010mode state on nodes [0,3] to |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \n  SPDC sources:  \n    Link A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    Link C\u2013D: modes [2\u20133]  \n    Squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla: modes [4\u20135]  \n          \u2198     \u2199  \n  Variational interferometer on modes [1,2,4] + vacuum ancillas [6,7]  \n          \u2193  \n  Detectors: [A_out=0],[D_out=3],[anc_sv=5],[vac1=6],[vac2=7]\n\nPytheus Configuration Snippet:\n```\n{\n  description: \"Variational squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010assisted entanglement swapping\",\n  foldername: \"VarSV_ES\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 3,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  probabilistic photon-pair sources: (0,1), (2,3), (4,5),\n  single_emitters: [],\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[1,3],[2,3],[3,4]],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  heralding_out: null,\n  anc_detectors: [5,6,7]\n}\n```\n\nKey Features:\n- Uses **three** SPDC pair\u2010sources: two build the initial links, one provides the squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla.\n- The **static** linear\u2010optics network at the repeater node mixes the ancilla mode with the two link modes and vacuum ancillas; all beam\u2010splitters and phases are **variational parameters** set by an outer optimizer.\n- Herald success by a click pattern on the three ancilla detectors; the averaged output on [0,3] approximates the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with maximal fidelity.\n- Fully within Pytheus\u2019s DV\u2013photon-pair, linear-optics, number-resolving framework; no cavities, feedback, or homodyne detection.\n\nGeneralization & Impact:\n- **Multi\u2010hop extension**: chain such squeezed\u2010vacuum\u2010enhanced swap modules to build a variational repeater.\n- **Resource trade\u2010off studies**: how much ancilla squeezing vs. network depth is needed under realistic loss.\n- Opens a new class of **variational non-Gaussian supermaps** in photonic quantum networks, blending continuous-variable resources with variational algorithm design.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core concept\u2014injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla into the swap node and tuning a static interferometer to boost heralded Bell fidelity\u2014duplicates the ensemble\u2019s squeezed-reservoir swapping scheme. A classical optimizer variationally tunes all beam-splitter angles and phase shifts in B\u2019s and D\u2019s interferometers to maximize the **heralded** fidelity (or negativity) of the A\u2013C state under realistic link noise.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n  SPDC EPR links:  \n    A\u2013B: modes [0\u20131]  \n    B\u2013C: modes [2\u20133]  \n    C\u2013D: modes [4\u20135]  \n    D\u2013A: modes [6\u20137]  \n\n  At node B:  \n    \u2022 Single-photon emitter \u2192 mode [8]  \n    \u2022 SPDC ancilla \u2192 modes [9\u201310]  \n    \u2022 Vacuum ancillas \u2192 modes [11,12]  \n    \u2022 Static, parameterized interferometer on [1,2,8,9,11,12]  \n\n  At node D:  \n    \u2022 Single-photon emitter \u2192 mode [13]  \n    \u2022 SPDC ancilla \u2192 modes [14\u201315]  \n    \u2022 Vacuum ancillas \u2192 modes [16,17]  \n    \u2022 Static, parameterized interferometer on [5,6,13,14,16,17]  \n\n  Detectors:  \n    \u2022 Outputs: A_out=0, C_out=4  \n    \u2022 Heralding: ancB_det=[9,11,12], ancD_det=[14,16,17]  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Snippet:\n```\n{\n  description: \"Variational photon-catalyzed percolation on 2\u00d72 SPDC square\",\n  foldername:   \"VarCat_Percolation\",\n  edges_tried:  40,\n  ftol:         1e-06,\n  loss_func:    \"cr\",\n  optimizer:    \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:      10,\n\n  # single-photon catalysis ancillas at B and D\n  single_emitters: [8,13],\n\n  # no direct cross\u2010links beyond the square\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,5],[0,7],\n    [4,1],[4,3],[4,6],[4,7]\n  ],\n\n  # we have 4 vacuum ancillas total (11,12,16,17)\n  num_anc: 4,\n  number_resolving: true,\n\n  # we\u2019ll define the successful heralding as \n  # a specific multi-click on [9,11,12] & [14,16,17]\n  heralding_out: null  \n}\n```\n\nWhy this is novel and within Pytheus\u2019s reach:\n\n1) Non-Gaussian supermap:  \n   Each node\u2019s circuit is not a standard Bell-measurement or CNOT-based filter, but a **photon-catalysis** operation: it mixes two link modes with a single-photon and a squeezervac ancilla, then heralds a multi-click pattern to enact a parity-selective filter that **boosts** probability of path percolation beyond any purely Gaussian scheme.\n\n2) Variational design:  \n   All beamsplitter angles and phases in B\u2019s and D\u2019s **static** interferometers become tunable parameters. A classical optimizer loops over these to maximize the A\u2013C output entanglement under realistic SPDC impurities\u2014this is exactly a variational quantum algorithm, but external to Pytheus.\n\n3) Purely within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit:  \n   \u2022 SPDC pair sources model both the links and the squeezers.  \n   \u2022 Single_photon_emitters supply the catalysis ancillas.  \n   \u2022 Static linear optics (beam splitters, phases) and number-resolving detectors implement the circuit.  \n   \u2022 Vacuum ancillas complete the network.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, cavities, homodyne, or state preparation beyond what Pytheus natively supports.\n\n4) Scalable & generalizable:  \n   \u2013 Chain more repeater squares or other topologies with the same catalysis module.  \n   \u2013 Study trade-offs between squeezing level, single-photon resource overhead, and network depth.  \n   \u2013 Opens a new avenue for **variational, non-Gaussian** quantum-network primitives\u2014beyond fixed entanglement swapping or teleportation.\n\nThis target combines a squeezed-vacuum resource with a variational quantum-algorithm framework in a non-Gaussian network transformation, without ever requiring forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback, making it a prime candidate for Pytheus to discover an explicit linear-optics design, and for you to write a compelling theory paper once the optical blueprint is in hand."
